Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and will it be submitted to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Name: Mrs. Emma H. Becker
Address: Broadwell, Saskatchewan
Birthplace: Crystal City, Missouri

1. INTRODUCTION

What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1907
Where did you set up housekeeping? In Manitoba
Where had you been living before that? In Manitoba
For how many people did you prepare meals? From two to twenty
How far was it to your nearest store? Small store, two miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Occasionally
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Only those needed. Bread, flour, cornmeal, rolled oats, sugar, salt, the bare necessities.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Lake & The Woods Flour, Ogden's Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? From 100 lbs. each to 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $1.35
How much did you use groats flour? Very little
Whole wheat flour? Very little
Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 1 mile that year? 1917
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes, Whole wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own oatmeal for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With the chopper we used to chop grain for stock. It was put through the chopper two or three times, to make it fine enough.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? From 5 lbs. to 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 58¢ per lb.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers Edwardsburg.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? From 6 oz. to 2 lb.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had our own cows.

Butter? Made our own.

Eggs? Had our own hens.

What was the price of butter? 15¢ per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, always.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cheddar cheese, also years old.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, pork, and fowl.

How did you get fresh meat? There were butchers who came through the country selling fresh beef and pork.

How often did you get fresh meat? About once a week.

How did you preserve meat? By the salt and sugar way, and by freezing during putting in glass vats, canning.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Sometimes.

If so what year was it organized? About 1917.

Did you use game? No.

For how long?

That part did fish play in the family diet?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Some fresh, some canned.

Kinds? Canned salmon, fresh white fish, pickled fish, smoked.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.
Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? ..............

To what extent? For our own use.

19. Were you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one or two local food products? Give details.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the early day I think we really had more substantial meals. I mean, meat, potatoes and other vegetables, and the old fashioned Rice Pudding baked in the oven with good fresh cows milk and such like. No little milk snacks such as different kinds of salads and fancy cooking and we always had hot porridge as we called it, Rolled Oats, Oatmeal, Cornmeal or ground wheat cooked. There was no option when our porridge was cooked we ate it and said nothing (This was in my Father's time).

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I never did rely on purchased foods, and I cooked and made my own. Only such things as Salt, Sugar, B. Powder & R. Soda, pepper and such like.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].
In the early days I think we really had many substantial meals. I mean, meat, potatoes and the vegetables, and the old fashioned rice pudding baked in the oven with good fresh cows milk and such like.

We didn't rush much, and we always had hot porridge and fancy eating, and we always had something (I say something) when we got up, and we always had something (I say something) when we went to bed.

And so on.

B. Pudding & Rice, pepper and onion.
